channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Shootout Underscores Fragile Truce in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: At least three people were killed Sunday at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk, days after a settlement was reached calling on insurgents to disarm.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators inspected two burnt vehicles on Sunday after a shootout at a checkpoint run by pro-Russian militants near the town of Slovyansk.

item.title: Scores Dead in Pakistani Bus Accident
item.description: At least 42 people, including 13 children, were killed after a bus collided with a trailer truck in southern Pakistan in one of the nation’s worst traffic accidents in years, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By ZIA ur-REHMAN and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Rescue workers attempting to pull passengers out of a bus after a deadly collision with a trailer truck on Sunday in the Sukkur district of southern Sindh Province.

item.title: Fractured State of Pakistani Taliban Calls Peace Deal Into Question
item.description: Infighting between commanders appears to be impeding talks with government negotiators, and recent bombings raise the possibility that the very idea of making peace has divided the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Clues to Family’s Business Ties Found in Public Paper Trail
item.description: Documenting the Zhou family investment tree to assess the vast wealth accumulated by the family of the former national security chief, who also ran the giant China National Petroleum Corp.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A web of intrigue surrounds China's investigation into the former security chief Zhou Yongkang and his family. Curious Chinese have started to visit his home village of Xiqiantou in eastern China, peeking inside his brothers' houses and snapping pictures at the Zhou family's ancestral grave.

item.title: Divers Begin Bringing Bodies Out of Capsized Ferry
item.description: As the death toll from the South Korean disaster reached 58, with more than 200 people still missing, officials said they expected weeks of grim recovery operations.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:description: Rescue workers moved the bodies of victims from Jindo-port on Jindo Island on Sunday.

item.title: Battle Rages in Homs, Hub of Revolt Against Assad Government
item.description: Syrian insurgents and antigovernment activists are reporting near-continuous bombardment of the Old City and the nearby neighborhood of Waer.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Security personnel and onlookers gathered Monday after a car bomb was detonated in Homs. Another went off on Friday.

item.title: U.N. Struggles to Stem Haiti Cholera Epidemic
item.description: The United Nations, facing a shortage of supplies to handle the epidemic, refuses to address whether its peacekeepers brought a deadly strain of the disease into the country.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Jacob Birnbaum, Champion of Soviet Jews, Dies at 88
item.description: Inspired by the civil rights movement, Mr. Birnbaum aimed at improving the lives of Soviet Jews and he contributed to legislation that eventually helped liberalize Moscow’s emigration policies.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Militant Group Says It Bombed Nigerian City
item.description: Islamic extremists claimed responsibility for an explosion that ripped through a busy bus station in Abuja, killing at least 75 people and wounding 141.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Submersible Seeking Jetliner May Soon Finish First Sweep
item.description: The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will continue even if the unmanned vessel combing the ocean floor off Western Australia finds nothing on its initial run, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Legal Twist in Bid to Reclaim Nazi-Looted Hospital
item.description: An Austrian case has become, depending on who is doing the talking, an example either of wrongful imprisonment, naked avarice or how feuds among heirs can complicate Holocaust restitution cases.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Milan Bures for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sanatorium Fürth, a onetime Vienna hospital stolen by the Nazis.

item.title: Investigating Family’s Wealth, China’s Leader Signals a Change
item.description: A corruption inquiry targeting the retired Communist Party leader Zhou Yongkang and his family could challenge a tacit rule that has allowed elite clans to accumulate vast wealth.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A visitor at the Zhou family’s ancestral graves in Xiqiantou, eastern China. Intrigue surrounds the family after a spate of arrests.

item.title: Critic of Pakistani Military Wounded in Karachi Attack
item.description: The brother of the Pakistani journalist who was shot accused the chief of Pakistan’s intelligence service of being responsible for the attack.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: 13 Suspected Militants Killed in Yemen
item.description: An airstrike killed 13 suspected Al Qaeda militants and three civilians in Yemen.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Pro-Russian Forces Work on Consolidating Power
item.description: In areas of eastern Ukraine under militant control, pro-Russian forces are stifling the news media and political dissenters.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: An Orthodox priest blessed pro-Russian activists on Saturday in Donetsk, Ukraine, in an area under pro-Russian militant control.

item.title: In Cold War Echo, Obama Strategy Writes Off Putin
item.description: President Obama wants to isolate Russia by cutting off its economic and political ties to the outside world, limiting its expansionist ambitions and effectively making it a pariah state.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia met Saturday with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev.

item.title: Breaking Proud Tradition, Captains Flee and Let Others Go Down With Ship
item.description: Lee Jun-seok became the second sea captain in two years to flee a sinking vessel when he left a South Korean ferry as terrified passengers were still struggling to get off.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and JAD MOUAWAD
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sketch of the capsized ferry stood near relatives waiting for missing passengers in South Korea.

item.title: Covert Inquiry by F.B.I. Rattles 9/11 Tribunals
item.description: The F.B.I.’s inquiry became the focus of the pretrial hearings at Guantánamo this week, after the contractor who was visited by the F.B.I. disclosed it to the defense team.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: News Analysis: Torment on the Stand, but Is It an Act?
item.description: Oscar Pistorius is either a traumatized person or a good actor. His histrionics are hard to read.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:credit: Pool photographs by Themba Hadebe and Siphiwe Sibeko (right)
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius reacting to testimony given at his murder trial on April 7.

item.title: About New York: A 12-Year-Old’s Trek of Despair Ends in a Noose at the Border
item.description: In the care of smugglers, a 12-year-old girl set out from Ecuador to join her parents, who had immigrated illegally to New York. She made it to Mexico before she died.
item.dc:creator: By JIM DWYER
item.media:description: Noemi Álvarez Quillay’s death in Mexico was ruled a suicide.

item.title: The Lede: Turkish Women Use Twitter to Fight Sexual Harassment
item.description: Thousands of Turkish women have taken part in a Twitter campaign to voice outrage at men who invade their space by spreading their legs while sitting next to them on buses and trains.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: French Journalists Are Freed in Syria
item.description: After 10 months in captivity in Syria, the French journalists were released on the Turkish-Syrian border on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: In Slovakia, Real Lottery Prize Goes to Tax Man
item.description: The idea of a new lottery in Slovakia is to encourage citizens to collect sales receipts and register them with the government, forcing restaurant and shop owners to pay the taxes they owe.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jozef Lazarcik, left, won a car after registering only nine receipts with Slovakia’s new tax lottery.

item.title: Captain and Two Crew Members Are Arrested in Korean Ferry Sinking
item.description: The captain, Lee Jun-seok, 69, was charged with abandoning the boat and its passengers at a time of crisis, among other counts, according to prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN and SU-HYUN LEE
item.media:credit: South Korean Coast Guard, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The Korean ferry's captain, Lee Jun-seok, was seen being rescued from the sinking vessel on Wednesday.

item.title: Deadliest Day: Sherpas Bear Everest’s Risks
item.description: An avalanche that left at least 13 dead has focused attention on the Sherpas, skilled high-altitude climbers who put themselves at great risk for the teams that pay them.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and GRAHAM BOWLEY
item.media:description: Mount Everest in 2009. An avalanche swept down a slope of Mount Everest on Friday, killing guides.
